author: Syed Muthahar Saqaf
text:
: In 1957 when the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (DMK) entered the electoral fray for the first time, its candidates contested as independent candidates as the party was not officially recognised by the Election Commission of India. Interestingly, some of the candidates had to seek votes on free symbols individually allotted to them.

The party founder C.N. Annadurai had fielded candidates in 112 Assembly constituencies and 11 Lok Sabha constituencies. Prominent among those who entered the fray were Annadurai in Kancheepuram; V. R. Nedunchezhian in Salem-I; M. Karunanidhi in Kulithalai; K. Anbazhagan in Egmore; N. V. Natarajan in Basin Bridge; A. V. P. Asaithambi in Thousand Lights; P. U. Shanmugam in Tiruvannamalai; noted lyricist Kannadasan in Tirukottiyur; actor S. S. Rajendran in Theni; and Sathiyavani Muthu in Perambur (Reserved constituency).

The party had made a request to the Election Commission to allot the ‘Rising Sun’, an independent symbol then, to all its candidates. But the Election Commission expressed its inability to oblige. However, it assured to allot the ‘Rising Symbol’ to DMK candidates wherever it was not demanded by other independents.

As such, a majority of the DMK candidates got the ‘Rising Sun’ symbol. A few DMK men got other symbols. Nedunchezhian was allotted the ‘Rooster’ symbol.

The DMK candidates faced many handicaps -- not having intimate knowledge of the constituencies and their voting behaviour, very little experience in campaigning, lack of resources and absence of an uniform election symbol. But the party managed to get 15 of its candidates elected including Messrs. Annadurai, Karunanidhi, Anbazhagan, Sathiyavani Muthu, Asaithambi, P. U. Shanmugam and M.P. Subramaniam (who later joined the Congress and became the TNCC president).

Nedunchezhian lost to a Congress candidate in Salem I seat by a mere 207 votes. Poet Kannadasan, S. S. Rajendran and Anbil Dharmalingam were the other notable DMK leaders who suffered a defeat.

The DMK won three seats in Chennai district, four seats each in South Arcot and North Arcot districts, two in Salem district, and one seat each in Tiruchi and Chengalpattu districts.

Two DMK leaders – E. V. K. Sampath and Dharmalingam – were elected to the Lok Sabha. Anna was elected as the DMK Legislature Party leader, K. Anbazhagan as his deputy and M. Karunanidhi as party whip.
title: When DMK candidates contested as Independents
